text: okay hello everyone my name is peter kibimaki i'm the cto of nordic institute
for interoperability solutions it's very nice to be here today i remember that the last live presentation
that i gave was in october 2019 since then i've i've given over 20
online presentations and quite many times never seeing the audience so
really good to be here today today my topic is secure data exchange in digital government context
and and first if we think about data exchange in digital government
context at a high level you can divide it into two different categories first
of all national data exchange meaning data exchange between different public
authorities and between public authorities and and private companies and of course there are several sub
categories when you think about the national context there are so many different way how it
can be organized but that's that's not essential today but the other high-level category is
cross-border data exchange which means that public authorities of two different
countries are exchanging data and when we think about those two
categories uh usually administrative and legal questions
they are a lot more challenging when it comes to cross-border data exchange on a
national level they are usually more straightforward but then there is also the technical
side of things and if you get data moving from a to b
once uh in general it's it's easier uh easy or easier at least to get it moving
again and in and when it comes to uh the the
technical side of the data exchange there are several solutions that can be
used some of them are more specialized on cross-border data exchange while others are national data exchange and
then there are also solutions that can do both and today i'm going to tell you about
one of those that can do both and it means that we are talking about
x-rate data exchange layer so xrode is a data exchange layer solution
that provides secure and unified way to exchange data between multiple organizations
xrod is published as open source under the mit license
and it's also a digital public good verified by the digital public good alliance
security is kind of the core of x-road what what it is and the the reason why
you would like to use x-road but i won't go into the details now you will hear
more about them later then xrode is also an enabler
when it comes to implementing the once only principle and the ones only principle
means that the citizens should provide with their data to public authorities
only once and then in case another authority needs the same data
the data is exchanged between the public authorities meaning that the citizen doesn't need to provide with his address
multiple times to different authorities then xrode is also very scalable
you can start small or go big immediately so xrode is based on decentralized
architecture and it's it's really easy to scale the implementation
the implementation is also very flexible meaning how how you
want to deploy it in the beginning i talked about different ways how to handle data
exchange on a national level well when it comes to x-ray the most typical way to deploy x-rays is to have one
national ex-road ecosystem and then all public authorities private companies all
kind of organizations can join it and this is how it has been implemented for example in estonia and in finland
but then there are countries that are federal states
and another model to deploy x-rays is that those different states can
independently deploy their own ex-road ecosystems and it means that wealth all
the states within the same federal state could have their own ex-road ecosystems and then they are
conducted or it can also be that the states end up using different data exchange
solutions some of them use x-rays some of them use something else and then
of course also a domain specific implementation model is
supported for example in estonia there is the estonian electricity grid operator
allering that has deployed an export ecosystem for european electricity grid
operators for sharing electricity metering data so
all all these kind of different models are are possible the technology doesn't set
any kind of limitations to them but then
to understand better what xroad really is and how it works
the best way to understand it is to compare it to point-to-point in the creases
so on the left-hand side you can see how point-to-point integrations work
well you probably are familiar with them but the main point here is that
every time when you build a new point-to-point integration you have to agree on all the details of the
integration and and of course configure set up everything and then in the long
run uh if if you have a lot of point to point in the creases uh maintaining them
it can be really complicated and especially uh if you want to enforce some specific let's
say security policies on a national level if you use point-to-point in the creations then it's it's really
challenging to enforce those policies but of course uh
it doesn't mean that point-to-point integrations are always bad if you have only very few information systems or
very few connections between them then point-to-point interfaces may be a feasible solution
but when thinking about uh a case where uh there are there's a
larger number of information systems and and connections between different information systems and and also when uh
when policies need to be enforced then x-ray is is a very good alternative
so the idea is that when x-ray is used information systems are not connected to
each other directly but instead they are connected through unified access points
called security servers as you can see from the right hand side diagram we have
three organizations all of them have their own security servers and their information
systems are are connected uh to each other through the security server so the
security server is kind of a access point gateway to the outside world
that guarantees that connections always always use the same security policies
configurations and and of course provide also a bunch of bunch of other features
and those features that export provides here's here's some of them mentioned so
for example address management and message routing the idea in x-road is that
all the different entities meaning organizations security servers services
they have identifiers and when services are invoked or access rights are managed
it happens through those identifiers and thanks to that
service consumer doesn't need to know where the service that that
is being involved is is actually located it's enough to know the identifier of
the service and send a request to the security server and security server does the
routing routing under the hood which means that the
physical network location of the service may be changed by the service owner and it
doesn't affect the consumers and same goes with the with certificates
so certificates of course they need to be renewed every now and then
and depending on the configuration sometimes changing a certificate on the
service provider side may require changes to all the consumers
but with x-rate that's never the case since xrode takes
care of distributing the certificates to all the parties of the ecosystem
well access rights management when a service provider publishes
service to x-rays the service provider the service owner remains in control who is allowed to
access the service publishing a service to x-ray doesn't mean that all the other
members of the ecosystem can automatically access it then organization level and machine to
machine level authentication x road uses certificates
so every security server has an authentication certificate and every organization has a signed certificate
uh and those are used to authenticate the security servers and and
organizations so ex-role thanks to this x-ray this kind of a trusted
peer-to-peer network of organizations
data transfer is an encrypted on transport level between the security
servers and all the all the messages that are sent they are digitally signed
timestamped and locked which means that xrode provides an evidence of every transaction that that
has been processed and that that log record it can be even used as
an evidence afterwards if if there is a dispute regarding some transaction and
the lock record tells what data was exchanged who were the
data exchange parties and when did the transaction take place
and here is a diagram that illustrates the x-ray architecture and this is a
simplification here we have just two organizations with their security
servers and and then of course the central components but in the real export ecosystem
of we have one set of central components but the number of organizations and
their security servers well depending on the size of the ecosystem it can be tens
or it can be hundreds but the main idea here is that we have a
data requester data provider they have their own security servers
and uh the data flows directly between the data requester and and data provider
no third parties have have access to the data and the security servers they take care
of those features that were listed listed in the previous slide
and of course the central components they are there for a reason too they
don't have an active role into data exchange but they play a very essential role when it comes
to establishing trust in the ecosystem so when a new organization joins
it must go through an onboarding process during which the certificate for the security server
and design certificate for the organization they they are applied and
issued by the trust service providers and once the organization has the
certificates it can complete the onboarding process and it becomes registered on the x road central servers
and once it has been registered there only after that it can start to exchange
data with other members of the ecosystem so even if xrod is open source anyone
can download the software install it but when we think about an existing
ecosystem for example in estonia you can just download the software and
and become member of the ecosystem just like that you have to go through the onboarding process during which your
identity is verified and thanks to that the ecosystem is is trusted and we know
the identities of other data exchange parties and usually the trust service providers
they are external commercial service providers

by a third party uh usually at least once a year or when there are bigger

then source code reviews they are a normal part of our development process
so merge requests they are never never
being merged before someone else has has reviewed it and and that that applies to everyone in

and usually when there is a new feature bigger change in the architecture we

and then of course we utilize automation as well so static source code analysis and automated dependency checks are are
being run all the time
besides a technical side x-road also has its own governance model
so the organization that runs the xrod ecosystem and is kind of the owner of
the ecosystem is the actual operator and the extra operator defines the rules and
and policies that the members of the ecosystem must follow and the operator also decides who
can become member of the ecosystem for example in estonia the export operator is the
estonian information system authority and in finland it's the finnish digital
agency and in the in the electricity grid operator case in
that case the x-rod operator is the estonian electricity grid operator
so they they decide how to run the ecosystem and when organizations join
the ecosystem they go through an onboarding process from technical perspective
but administratively they also must sign a service agreement with the operator
they must agree with the with the rules and policies of the ecosystem
and the member organizations they can be service consumers service pro or service
providers or or both and when you set up the security server
you can do you can use it for all these different roles the software doesn't set any any

service provider usually need to have an have an agreement of course open data is an
exception but if we think about something something
more confidential for example personal data vehicle data what base registries that the public sector

first the central components of explode they need to be connected it's very
